loans.name: Khureltuya

texts.en: Khureltuya is 49 and the father of two children. He and his family live together in a ger (the Mongolian nomadic tent). His son who is aged 18 is a university student and the youngest one attends local secondary school. His wife works at the local kindergarten as an assistant teacher. He bought a minivan and started his transportation business in 2000. His route goes from Ulaanbaatar city to the outskirts of the city. He has gained valuable experience in previous years and has a loyal customer base. He is building a new house on their plot of land and wants to complete the construction work on the house. The loan he is asking for will be used to buy some construction materials for his uncompleted house. He is a very hardworking and reliable person.

loans.use: To buy construction materials for his uncompleted house.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina V. is from the village of Cabisera 17-21. She is 28 years old. Angelina is married and has two infant children. To make a living, Angelina owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Angelina has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Angelina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelina is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Angelina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong K., 38, is widowed and resides with a child in Bonteay Meanchey Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Temples complex near Siem Reap province. K. sells dessert and Chinese noodle, earning an income of USD 5 per day. The family has to spend USD 50 on food, USD 50 on the kid’s education, and USD 15 on other necessary expenses every month.  K. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Hun

texts.en: Hun V., 27, is married and resides with his wife and a child in Bonteay Meanchey Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Temples complex near Siemp Reap province. V. is a barber earning an income of USD 6 per day. The family has to spend USD 50 on food, USD 15 on water and electricity, and USD 10 on other necessary expenses every month.  V. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase more barber supplies to improve his business. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more barber supplies

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard is a dairy farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley Kenya. He has been farming for 15 years and employs one farmhand. His farm produces milk which he sells locally. He also earns income from his small-scale farming of tea which he sells to the local market. His primary challenge has been low production of milk which affects his income.

Bernard is 52 years old.  He is married with eight school-aged children, all of whom attend school.

He has requested this loan of 50,000KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help him to pay the school fees for his children. In the future, he would like to expand his dairy farming by acquiring more dairy cows.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Ret

texts.en:
Mr. Ret R. has been selling jars for more than three years. His wife, Mrs. Thary Hong, raises pigs at home. They live along National Road Number Six, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City and have been married since 2004. 

In the past, Ret bought jars from his village. Now he operates a business producing jars by himself at his home. He asked for a Kiva loan one time already. He now is requesting another loan for $500 to produce jars for sale.

Mr. Ret R. was not available for the picture so his wife is pictured.

loans.use: To produce jars for sale.

loans.name: Khen

texts.en: Khen V., 25, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia, an area known for a business area with Vietnam. V. produces rice wine, earning an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of about USD 5 per day. The family has to spend USD 33 on food, USD 5 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 15 on other necessary expenses every month.  V. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a plot of farmland to produce more rice. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. V. appears in the photograph with her family.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland to produce more rice

loans.name: Lalbek

texts.ru: Шодавронов Лалбек проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 51 год. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена работает в больнице врачом. Сам Лалбек имеет средне - специальное образование, фармацевт. По профессии работает уже 30 лет. У него собственная аптека. Кредит берет для приобретения лекарств и новых препаратов.
texts.en: Lalbek S. lives in Vahdat.  He is 51 years old, married, and has five children. His wife works in a hospital as a doctor.  Lalbek has a vocational education as a pharmacist. He has been working in his trade for thirty years.  He owns a drugstore.  He is taking out a loan to buy medicines and compounds.

loans.use: Buying medicines and compounds

loans.name: Sambat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sambat V. (pictured with her loom) has been a silk weaver since 1980. Her husband, Mr. Set Sam, is a primary-school teacher. They have been married since 1979 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. Two of them are married and live outside the family home, two assist their mother in the business and another one is in school.

Mrs. Sambat V. has requested a Kiva loan two times already. She is now requesting her third loan for $200 to purchase weaving materials to continue her weaving business. Weaving is the business that Sambat has been doing for a long time.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida T. is from the village of Cabisera 17-21. She is 28 years old. Aida is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Aida owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Aida has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Aida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Aida is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Aida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Najma's Group

texts.en:
Najma lives in Gujranwala, which is famous for its dairy business in Pakistan. She lives there in a two-room brick house with her family. She moved to Gujranwala after her marriage. She has four sons and two daughters. All of them except the last two are illiterate and couldn’t get an education due to financial constraints. They do different kinds of work to financially contribute to their family. Her eldest son works in a factory. The next two work in a motor workshop as motor mechanics. Her elder daughter is involved in the football stitching business. She collects orders from football manufacturing factories and earns good money by completing them on time. The other kids are getting their education from a local school. Najma also supports her elder daughter in her business of stitching footballs so she can complete the orders on time. Her husband, S. A., works in a motor-workshop as a motor mechanic and repairs vehicles of his customers. 
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her daughter’s business of stitching footballs. With the loan, she will buy a football sewing machine to fulfill the orders on time. She is hopeful that with the machine she and her daughter will be able to get a large number of orders and also complete them on time. This will also affect their earnings and that will suitably help them to improve the living standard of their family. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Najma.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine to sew footballs

loans.name: Eliza

texts.en:
Eliza T. is from the village of Cabisera 17-21. She is 42 years old. Eliza is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Eliza owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Eliza has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Eliza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Eliza is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Eliza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Pheouk

texts.en: Pheouk S., 50, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia, an area known for a business area with Vietnam. S. and her husband produce Cambodian noodles, earning an income of USD 5 per day. The family has to spend USD 44 on food, USD 5 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 20 on other necessary expenses every month.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a machine to produce more noodles. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S. appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: To buy a machine to produce more noodles

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie A. is from the village of Cabisera 17-21. She is 47 years old. Josie is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Josie owns & operates a business venture raising pigs for fattening and sale. Josie has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells her raised pig.

In 2009, Josie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. Josie is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Josie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future

loans.name: Lung

texts.en: Lung B., 40, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kandal Province, Cambodia, an area known for fertile farmland for growing vegetables. B. and her husband sell vegetables, especially cucumbers, earning an income of USD 3 per day. Also, her husband grows beans at home to generate more income. The family has to spend USD 35 on food, USD 7 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 15 on other necessary expenses every month.  B. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a motorbike to transport vegetables to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. B.'s husband appears in the photograph because B. was not available.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport vegetables

loans.name: Mahmood Akhter's Group

texts.en:
M. akhter is a resident of Gujranwala, which is located in Punjab Pakistan known for its dairy industry. She is a housewife who prefers to stay at home and manage her household responsibilities. Her husband, R. A., is a private entrepreneur and has a cosmetics selling business. He operates his cosmetics shop in the market. He sells make-up items such as lipsticks, nail polishes, hair colors, facial creams etc.  

M. is the mother of a son and a daughter. Her son left his education after completing his 12th standard and started helping his father in his cosmetics business. Her daughter is very talented and operates her sewing business at her home. 

M. herself is a vigorous lady. She is involved in a business stitching footballs. She collects order from different football manufacturing factories and earns a good profit by completing the orders on time. She does this work to supplement the income of her family. 

M. has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s cosmetics business. With the loan, her husband will add more variety of cosmetics in his cosmetics shop and increase his selling. M. is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan application. In previous loan years, she has paid her installments on time and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy cosmetic items for cosmetics selling business

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Sao S., 28, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kandal Province, Cambodia, an area known for fertile farmland for growing vegetables. S. is employed at a factory earning an income of USD 1.60 per day. Her husband sells phones earning an income of about USD 1.80 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family has to spend USD 30 on food, USD 5 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 10 on other necessary expenses every month.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more phones to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. was not available.

loans.use: To buy more phone to sell

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna S. is from the village of Cabisera 17-21. She is 29 years old. Lorna is married and has three infant children. To make a living, Lorna owns & operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells one of her raised animals.

In 2008, Lorna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Lorna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future

loans.name: Nov

texts.en:
Nov C., age 54, is married to Mr. Mey, age 57. He appears in the photo. She has four children, three of whom are employed as garment workers. The other one attends school. 

Her husband has been earning a living for many years. He is a porter in his community, or anywhere in the province of Kompong Tom. This family normally earns an average of $5 per day to help cover their family’s daily living expenses. The main source of income comes from her three daughters who receive a regular salary each month. 

In the past until the present, Nov C. said that her daughters face difficulties with getting to work, and they always pay for hiring a taxi. To reduce the cost of transportation, Nov C. would like a $450 loan in order to buy a secondhand motorbike for her daughters to drive to work.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motorbike for her daughter to drive work.

loans.name: Yormahmad

texts.ru: Аюбов Ёрмахмад проживает в районе Хуросон. Возраст, 52 года. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена, занимается шитьем национальных платьев. Сам Ёрмахмад имеет средне - специальное образование, парикмахер. По профессии проработал 30 лет. Сейчас он занимается животноводством. Разводит скот у себя дома. Он в основном разводит скот в дальнейшем для перепродажи. В этой области уже 15 лет. Кредит берет для закупа крупно - рогатого скота.
texts.en: Yormahmad A. lives in Khuroson.  He is 52 years old, married, and has four children. His wife works sewing traditional dresses.  Yormahmad has a vocational education as a hairdresser. He has worked in his trade for thirty years.  Now he works in animal husbandry. He raises cattle at home.  He primarily raises cattle for resale.  He has been doing this for fifteen years.  He is taking out a loan to buy cattle.

loans.use: Buying cattle

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn I. is from the village of Libag Sur, Tuguegarao City. She is 19 years old. Marilyn is married and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, she raises pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marilyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her 3rd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 34 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine F. is from the village of Cabisera 17-21, Isabela. She is 34 years old. Josephine is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine raises pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $100 when she sells her raised pig.

In 2009, Josephine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. 

Josephine is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Misbah's Group

texts.en:
Misbah lives in a two-room brick house in Gujranwala, which is a small city located in Punjab Pakistan and famous for its dairy industry. She is a very talented lady and operates a business of stitching soccer balls. She collects orders from different manufacturing factories and earns well by sewing their footballs on time. She does this work to help her husband financially.  

Her husband, M. Y., has a business of selling bedsheets. He buys bedsheets from the cities of Multan and Lahore and sells them in different areas of the community to generate income.  He has been doing this business for the last five years.  

Misbah is the mother of three daughters and two sons. Three of them couldn’t manage to get an education. She has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy bedsheets in bulk quantity and increase his sales.  

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has proven herself as a responsible client who always paid her installments on time and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy bedsheets in bulk for reselling

loans.name: Abdallah

texts.en:
Abdallah is 55 years old and married with four school-aged children who all attend school. He is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya. He has been farming for ten years and employs one farmhand. His farm is currently producing milk at a low quantity which is only enough for the family's consumption. He also earns income from his spare-parts shop.

Abdallah has requested this loan of 60,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to expand his poultry business. He says that the proceeds from his poultry business will go towards the education of his children. He says that his major challenge has been disease which is too expensive to treat. In the future, he would like to expand his farm and venture fully into dairy farming.

loans.use: To expand his poultry project.

loans.name: Lodivina

texts.en:
Lodivina A. is from the village of Cabisera 17-21. She is 34 years old. Lodivina is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately $100 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lodivina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Lodivina is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Baldirmaa

texts.en:
Baldirmaa R. is 44 years old and lives with her husband and four daughters in Baganuur, one of the remote districts of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family all live together in their own apartment. Her older two daughters are students at the universities and her younger two daughters attend a school. Her husband works as fire hydrant cleaner for a company. 

Baldirmaa operates a used item retail business. She sells a variety of secondhand clothing and shoe items for both children and adults. She started her business in 2000 and since then has built a stable operation and has gained much experience as a businesswoman. Baldirmaa is a modest, honest and responsible woman and says, "I want to expand my business and open a new branch of my store in the future." She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase blankets, pants, shoes and bed covers to sell at her business.

loans.use: To purchase blankets, pants, shoes and bed covers

loans.name: Gulshan's Group

texts.en:
Gulshan belongs to a city called Gujranwala, which is famous for its dairy industry in Punjab, Pakistan. She lives with her family in a two-room brick house. She moved to Gujranwala after her marriage many years ago. Her husband, W., operates his grocery shop in the market. Through the shop he fills the orders of his customers by selling required daily use items. 

Gulshan also contributes to her family financially with her sewing business. She sews clothes at her home. She mainly receives orders from her neighbors and earns well after completing the orders on time. Due to the quality of her work, she receives regular orders. 

She is the mother of four sons and a daughter. Her three elder sons and her daughter work to financially support the family. Her eldest son has a utensil-selling business. The next son drives a rickshaw, providing transport services to his passengers. The third son works in a factory for a monthly wage. Her daughter is involved in the sewing business.
 
Gulshan has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s grocery shop. With the loan, her husband will buy groceries such as cooking oil, rice, soaps, spices, etc. in bulk quantities for selling at his shop. She is hopeful that her husband, who has vast experience in his business, will surely be able to improve his store with the help of this investment. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy grocery items for grocery shop

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
Im M. is a 44-year-old farmer who lives in Kompong Tom Province. She is married to Mr. Sok, age 51, who is a local chef. Im M.’s husband is always hired by neighbors to cook meals for their wedding parties and their other ceremonies. 

This couple has four children, one of whom is married and the other three are single. Im M. has a son who is not yet working. She wants to encourage her son to have a job, but she has no cash to make that possible. So, she is requesting a loan to purchase a used motorcycle for her son to provide transportation for a fee.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorcycle for her son to provide transportation for a fee.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes J. is currently in the business of selling food items in Konyokonyo market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of rice to sell. She is 20 years old and married. Her husband is a security guard.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: Stock bags of rice to sell

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen resides in Gujranwala, which is famous for its dairy industry in Pakistan. She is a 44-year-old housewife who spends most of her time staying at home and doing her household work. She is married to L. M. who is a government employee and earns a meager income. She is a mother of four sons and three daughters. She couldn’t educate her elder children due to poor financial condition but as her elder son started working, she has managed to enroll her last four children in school and they are continuing their education. Her son is involved in the furniture making & selling business. He makes furniture on orders and earns a good profit on each order. 

Nasreen has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her son’s business. With the loan, her son will buy wood, nail and furniture polish in bulk quantity. The bulk quantity will enable him to make more furniture on time and earn maximum profit.  

Nasreen is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In the previous loan year, she has built a good credit record and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Nasreen.

loans.use: To buy wood, nails and furniture polish for furniture making & selling business

loans.name: Naranjargal

texts.en: Naranjargal B. is 32 years old and lives with her husband and  two small children in an apartment in Baganuur, one of the remote district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her husband works as a musician in the Military force. Her two children attend local kindergarten. Naranjargal has been working as a beautician since 2004 and has gained much experience. Naranjargal is a modest, honest and responsible woman. She says, "I would like to open my own beauty salon in the future." She is requesting a 150,000 MNT loan to purchase face massage cream, towel, and facemask for her beauty service.

loans.use: To purchase massage cream and towels

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes D. is currently in the business of selling tea and cold drinks and is requesting a loan to stock more cold drinks and sugar.  Agnes is 24 years old and is married to a loader. She has one child and her child does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: To stock more cold drinks and sugar

loans.name: C1184 Jyambere Group

texts.en:
Laurence is was born in 1964 and is married with two children; the first one is 5 years old and the younger is two years old. Laurence is businesswoman and her husband is also in business; both work hard for the purpose of making progress in their family. Laurence owns a small business selling soft drinks made of sorghum and she has two years of experience. The hours of her daily activities are from 6 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day. In addition to that, Laurence is the group leader of eleven people who have different business; some of them sell  juice made of bananas or have a store with various products and so on.

Laurence and her group are now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their business through purchasing the products needed. With this loan the members of group will be able to satisfy their business customers which will be the best way of earning more profits to be used in their families and in their business as well.

loans.use: purchasing the sorghum for making soft drinks

loans.name: Slamas

texts.en:
Mrs. Slamas M. and her husband, Mr. El M., have been married since 1978 and have ten children; three sons and seven daughters. They live along National Road Number Six about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Mrs. Slamas M. sells fish that her husband caught and she buys some from her neighbors and resells them on the other side of the Mekong River. Her husband is a fisherman and a construction worker. 

Slamas asked for a Kival loan to purchase fishing materials for her husband’s fishing business. They are elderly and it is becoming more difficult difficult for him to operate the business. Therefore, Slamas is requesting another loan of $800 to purchase new fishing materials for her husband to continue his fishing business. 

Photo: is Mrs. Slamas M.

loans.use: To purchase new fishing materials for her husband’s fishing business.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda Y. is from the village of Villa Nueva. She is 56 years old. Erlinda is single. To make a living, Erlinda owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 12000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Erlinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand product offering. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 40000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Erlinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 34 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary K. is currently in the business of selling groundnut phase and is requesting a loan to stock more groundnuts to make phase to sell.  Mary is 28 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant. She has 4 children and 2 of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a house and pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: To stock more groundnuts to make phase to sell

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma A. is from the village of Cabisera 17. She is 44 years old. Alma is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Alma owns & operates a business venture in the services sector providing transportation business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle transport in the local community. Alma has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Alma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair existing vehicle for better service. Alma is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional vehicle for the business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Alma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional vehicle for the business

loans.name: C5282 Icyerekezo Group

texts.en:
Celestin is 28 years old, married with one child who is 2 years old. Celestin is a businessman; he owns a little restaurant. This business is profitable that's why it was chosen by him even though he works himself. He is group representative for 8 members, each one with his own business. Celestin in particular has an experience of 3 years and the hours of his business are from 6 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day.

Celestin and his group members are requesting a Kiva loan Via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding their businesses through purchasing more products. Celestin needs to purchase more foodstuffs which will allow him to provide more customers with meals. Hopefully; Celestin will be able to earn some profits; with these profits he expects to earn he will be able to save money and to reinvest in his business.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeun K. is 47 years old (was in the photo), and her husband, Mr. Chhoeun Oeun is 46 years odd, have been married since 1986 and have three children: one son and two daughters. One of them married and lives outside the family home. One of her children is a garment factory worker and another one attends school. The family lives in the area surrounding Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Mrs. Soeun K. and her husband are fishermen. They fish from the lake nearby their house and sell to a middleman who comes to buy them at their home. The couple hopes to supplement a new business of raising ducks. They will be able to generate income to better support their family. 

Hence Soeun is asking for her first loan in the amount of $600 to establish the business.

loans.use: To use for raising ducks.

loans.name: Ericson

texts.en:
Ericson D. is from the village of Dalig Viejo. He is 30 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ericson owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising pigs for breeding. Ericson has been engaged in his business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Ericson joined Kiva partner, ASKI ,to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be his first from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's general living conditions.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes J. is 19 years old and single. She is currently in the business of distilling and selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to stock more brewing materials. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: To stock more brewing materials

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher is 54 years old. He is married with four children, only one of whom attends school. He is a dairy farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya. He has been farming for over six years and employs two farmhands. His farm produces milk, which he sells to the local market. He also earns income from the sale of maize and bananas to the local market. His biggest challenge has been diseases, which are costly to treat.
Christopher has requested this loan of 41,600 KES from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The proceeds from this loan will help him in paying school fees for his child at university. He will also be able to provide enough food for his family. In future, he would like to purchase a pick-up to assist him in transporting his farm produce to the market. He appreciates Juhudi's good will to assist small-scale farmers who have been shunned by the banks.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Otgonjargal

texts.en: Otgonjargal L. is 32 years old and lives with her husband in Baganuur, one of the remote districts of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The couple lives in an apartment. Otgonjargal's husband works as a guard in a health resort. Otgonjargal has been operating a clothes trading business from a stall in her area. She provides a variety of women's clothes and consumer goods to satisfy her customer's needs. Otgonjargal is focused on expanding her retail business and purchasing a house for her family in the future. She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more products to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more products

loans.name: Doem

texts.en:
Doem S. is 47 years of age and married. In order to meet her family's needs, Doem S. sells a little grocery inventory in Phnom Penh. She has twenty years' experience in this sector and earns approximately $3 per day. To help contribute to her family, her husband works as a chief of construction workers in the city.
The couple have been married for years and have six children– four of whom are single. Doem S. says that one of her children is to get married soon, but her savings are insufficient to prepare for the wedding. To solve this problem, Doem S. has requested a loan of $800 to be used to prepare for her child's wedding.

loans.use: To prepare for her child's wedding

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose N. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and beer and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer and bags of charcoal to sell.  Rose is 25 years old and her husband is in the military. She has no children yet.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer and bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Randy

texts.en:
Randy S. is from the village of Divisoria Santiago. He is 35 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Randy owns and operates a transportation business providing motorcycle transport in the local community. Randy has been engaged in his business for over eight years and earns approximately 3,100 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2008, Randy joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. Randy is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be his sixth from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida A., from the village of Cabaruan, is 43 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Zenaida owns and operates a business venture raising pigs for fattening and sale. Engaged in her business for over a year, she earns approximately 4000 PHP monthly.

In 2009, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 4000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future, she is now requesting her third loan of 8000 PHP to be used for the same purpose. Zenaida plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 34 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future

loans.name: Ma.theresa Erma

texts.en:
Ma. Theresa Erma T. is a married woman who lives in Sitio Sutay, Brgy. Antipolo, Pontevedra, Negros Occidental. She earns a living by operating three business ventures: food vending, a general store and a tricycle transport business. Her husband, Fausto, who is 49 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living and he also helps in his wife's businesses. They have five children aged between 7 and 27. 
Ma. Theresa Erma joined Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ma. Theresa Erma has been gradually lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 17,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 6,100 PHP, thus raising her family's standard of living. This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing 19,000 PHP, which she intends to use to process the documents for her daughter to work abroad so that she could continue to save up for the future education of her children. 
Ma.Theresa Erma T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

 About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund the operation of her food business

loans.name: Samoeu

texts.en:
Mrs. Samoeu L., 50, and her husband, Mr. Phany Chhauk, 53, have two children-a son who is in university, and a daughter who assists her parents in the business. The family lives in a village aL. National Road Number Two about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Samoeun and her husband grow and sell small trees and flowers at their home. She is now requesting a loan of $600 to pay school fees for her son and grow more small trees and flowers to sell.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her son and grow small trees and flowers for sale.

loans.name: Sin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sin K. is 57 and her husband, Mr. Touch Doung, is 67. They have been married since 1976 and have seven children – four sons and three daughters. Five of their children are married and live outside the family home and the other two are factory workers. They live along National Road Number 1, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. The couple are elderly, but they are strong enough to work.
Mrs. Sin K. and her husband are farmers. They grow vegetables on their farmland in the village where they live. Sin is asking for her first loan of $500 to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her vegetable farm.
The photo shows Mrs. Sin K. and her husband.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Perla D., from the village of Sta Rosa, is 40 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Perla owns and operates a business venture raising pigs for fattening and sale. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Perla joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 13000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future, she is now requesting her eighth loan for 15000 PHP to be used for the same purpose. Perla plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 38-year-old married man who lives with his wife and five children in Tyre. Ali does a lot of things in order to provide the best standard of living he can afford to his big family. Since 1989, he has worked in construction and is an expert in cement work. Since 1998, he has sold chickens, either live or ready to be cooked. Since 2006 he has owned a bus to transport students to and from school. In addition, he has a new private business buying and selling used cars.
This is the second time that Ali has requested a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua. His last loan greatly affected his family's financial situation. This time he is requesting a loan in order to support his car trading business, since this business is new.
Ali is an ambitious man and a hard worker. His customers are seeking him out as his reputation is spreading among nearby villages. He hopes to stay in such an ambitious situation, and hopes to satisfy his family's needs.

loans.use: To support his car trading business

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en: Sabina S. is from the village of Brgy. Uddiawan, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 55 years old. Sabina is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Sabina makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Sabina has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 4,500 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2006, Sabina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sabina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Sabina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Sabina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Namperi

texts.en:
Namperi S. J. is a married lady with three children aged between 5 and 13 years. Her business is located at a busy market in Mariakani, Mombasa, Kenya, and is well-known by the name Namperi Cereals. 

Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and it is well-known for its many, many tourist attraction sites, not forgetting the Indian ocean's white beaches. 

She has been selling such items as maize and french beans for the last 10 years to the local people. She has managed to employ one person. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is the slow movement of stock in some seasons. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to diversify her business by buying cabbages and carrots to resell at a profit. She hopes to be the largest supplier of cereals in Mariakani. She also sees herself buying a car to help her transport the cereals in future. She describes herself as focused.

loans.use: Potatoes and carrots

loans.name: Kem

texts.en:
Kem T., 55, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kandal Province, Cambodia, an area known for fertile farmland for growing vegetables. 

T. is a farmer and raises animals, earning an income of $2 per day. Her husband is motor-taxi driver, earning an income of about $2 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family has to spend $20 on food, $5 on electricity and water supplies and $15 on other necessary expenses every month.  

T. is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase cows to raise for sale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: Buy cows to raise for sale

loans.name: Crisanta

texts.en:
Crisanta D. is from the village of Divisoria Santiago. She is 55 years old, widowed and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Crisanta owns and operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Crisanta has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Crisanta joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Crisanta is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 34 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida J. is from the village of Simmimbaan. She is 48 years old. Zenaida is married and has three grown children. To make a living, Zenaida raises livestock, primarily pigs for breeding. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for more than 25 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Zenaida is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which she will use to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Hicham

texts.en: Hicham is a 37-year-old married man living in Tyre. He has been working as a plumber and in sanitary work since 1988, with 25 years of experience. Hicham is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to start a new business. He wants to sell home appliances and to participate in the mobile markets that pass by the nearby villages. Hicham believes that these markets can help him increase his income and improve his financial situation. His clients are his neighbors, relatives and friends as well as most construction contractors. He hopes to become strong in the field of home appliance sales in order to open a big showroom in the future.

loans.use: To start a new business

loans.name: Chhung

texts.en: Chhung M. is 42 years old and mother to five children. Four are single and the other is married and has already started a new family. Her husband is a motor taxi driver who has spent almost his whole life in motor taxi service. In the beginning of 2005, Chhung M. built a small store in Phnom Penh City. In her shop, she sells a few snack products, fast foods, sweets and grocery items to people near her store and those who pass by. Unfortunately, her husband’s motor has often broken down. Because of this problem, Chhung M. would like a loan to buy a used motor to replace the broken one and to buy a cart for her husband.

loans.use: To buy a used motor to replace the broken one and a cart for her husband.

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena G., from the village of Bayabo East, is 49 years old, married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Rowena owns and operates a specialized retail store selling raw and salted eggs in the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2005, Rowena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid a previous loan of 16000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting her 10th loan of 18000 PHP to be used for the same purpose. Rowena plans to pay the tuition fees of her children with the additional revenue generated from the business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 34 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Long T. N. is 52 years old and has 1 child. She has been running a grocery shop in the local market for 6 years. Her shop is not big but it generates a reasonable income. With this income she she can manage her family life and save money for a motor for her child who is going to go to work. Since joining our credit program in 2004, she has been a good repayer. Currently, she wants a loan of 9,810,000 VND to buy more products to meet customer demand.

loans.use: to buy more products to meet customer demand

Precy has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 4,500 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. loans.name: Liverson Kulei

texts.en:
Liverson Kulei Mnyala is a 38-year-old  sole-proprietor retail shop owner in Kiwanda,  Kilifi. He is married to Margarate Tsuma and together they are blessed with three children. Liverson has been a retail shop owner for the last eight years and is doing very fine. 

He has applied for his third loan with KADET and he intends to purchase more bags of sugar and bales of floor (maize and wheat).  The anticipated profit will be used to pay school fees for his children.

He hopes his business will continue to flourish in future so that he can be able to give his children a better education.

loans.use: buying more bales of flour and sugar

loans.name: Gloria Bicoy Group

texts.en:
Gloria B. is from Dimaluna, Ozamis City. She is 49 years old, is married and has four adult children. Gloria is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Gloria B. Group. 

Gloria owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In July 2009, Gloria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Gloria is now requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her fourth taken from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.







About Group Loans 

In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is a 32-year-old married man living in Tyre with his wife and only child. Mohammad has owned a grocery store since 2007, with four years of experience in the field. He used to sell mobile phones, but he realized that a food business brings in a better income, so he’s working hard on improving this business to insure a better living for his family. 

Mohammad has a disability concerning his eyesight, but for him it was never an obstacle, and he insists on overcoming any obstacle or difficulty. Mohammad is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the third time, in order to buy new products to his store and to increase his working capital. 

Mohammad states that the previous loans were of great benefit and they helped in increasing his income. Mohammad’s a man with a good reputation; his customers like the quality of products he sells in his store. Mohammad hopes to expand his store.

loans.use: To buy new products for his store

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 24-year-old married man living in Tyre with his beloved wife, owner of a manakish bakery. Manakish, also manaqish, manaeesh or manakeesh or in singular form man'ousheh (Arabic: مناقيش‎ manāqīsh; sometimes called معجنات mu‘ajjanāt 'pastry'), is a popular Levantine food consisting of dough topped with thyme, cheese, or ground meat. Similar to a pizza, it can be sliced or folded, and it can either be served for breakfast or lunch. 

The word manaqish is the plural of the Arabic word manqūshah (from the root verb naqasha 'to sculpt, carve out'), meaning that after the dough has been rolled flat, it is pressed by the fingertips to create little dips for the topping to lie in. Traditionally, Arab women would bake dough in a communal oven in the morning, to provide their family with their daily bread needs. They would prepare smaller portions of dough with different toppings for breakfast at this time. 

Ali has been a pastry baker since 2004. He makes delicious pastries that no one can resist. Ali is requesting a loan for the fourth time from Al Majmoua, in order to increase his raw materials, and to pay what’s left of the price of his house sanitary ware and furniture. Ali is very competent and hopes to maintain stability in his work and life.

loans.use: To increase his raw materials

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a farmer from Murang'a town in central Kenya where he has been farming for 30 years. His mixed farm produces coffee, milk and horticultural products that he sells to the local market. He mainly depends on the income from his farming activities to cater for the needs of his family. John is 57 years old. He is married with eight children who are all adults. One of his children is currently attending school.

He has requested this loan of 38,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo for rabbit keeping. He hopes that this project will increase the income for his family and assist in paying school fees for his son. His biggest challenge has been drought and lack of a reliable market for rabbit meat. He hopes that in future he will be able to expand his agri-business to even practice poultry farming.

He comments that the future is bright with financial support from Juhudi Kilimo.

loans.use: For rabbit keeping
